HE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 1.
MEDICAL SCHOOL
Reopens Session for the Year With a
Large Entering Class.

The Medical Department of the
University opened its session on
Tuesday, October 4. According to
expectation, the entering class is a
large one, about 115 being enrolled
so far. There are also about 25
entering with advanced standing,
an unusually large number.
Among the new students known
in Baltimore are the following:
John T. King, Jr. (Princeton,
'ro); Miss Mabel Belt (Goucher,
'To); Miss Alma Rothholz (Smith,
'Jo); Alan C. Woods(Johns Hopkins, ro); Miss M. L. Frazee (Goucher, 'o8) • Walter C. Haupt (Ph.
D. Johns Hopkins, 'o8).
Among the former students returning, none received a heartier
welcome than Hampden, of the second year, who was forced to leave
his classes by illness during the
past winter.
Several minor improvements to
the grounds have been made during
the summer. The handsome new
concrete wall around the north side
of the lot, which was wrecked just
as it was completed by the severe
storm of September i has now
been entirely repaired and will soon
be turned over by the contractors.
A similar wall now replaces the former unsightly wall of the Hunterian Laboratory. Returning students were also interested in the
progress of the new buildings in
the Hospital grounds. The Harriet
Lane Home and the addition to the
Pathological Building have nearly
reached completion, and the longdelayed Phipps Clinic is fairly under way.
The expected radical change in
the schedules has not entirely materialized, but a step has been taken
by devoting the whole of one day
to the physiological laboratory work
of the second year. The new entering class will take this work in
their first year, in the Spring Trimester.
Mr. Allen of the second class,
is the new member of the Students'
Book Store.
The lectures on the Herter Foundation will be given on October 5,/'
6 and 7 in the Physiological Building by Dr. Hans Chiari, Professor
of Pathological Anatomy at Strassburg, Germany. His subjects are
as follows:
October 5-Die Bedeutung des
Amnoin far die Entstehung von
Missbildungen des Menschen.
• October 6-Pankreasnecrose.
October 7-Spondylolisthesis.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 5, 1910.
Physicians and medical students
are invited to attend. The lectures
will be delivered in German-the
G. \V. C.
hour is 4 P. M.

Charles E. Brooks, 'oo, Ph. D.,
04, has been appointed professor of

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
ATHLETIC BOARD MEETS
Football Managers Selected-Fulton and
Pieper Elected Temporary Captains-Board for This Year.

At the first meeting of the Athletic Board last Thursday afternoon,
Billie Haynes was elected manager
of the football team to succeed
Freddie Lee, who resigned. J. E. L.
Holmes was elected assistant manager. Jack Fulton was chosen as
temporary captain of the track team
until the members of the team can
get together and select their leader.
Fulton would make a good captain,
and his election will probably be
confirmed by the team. Harry
Burgan, who managed the track
team so efficiently last season, refused to accept the position again
and Harold B. Hering was chosen
to succeed him.
Pieper, one of the leading spirits
of last year's Independent Nine,
was elected temporary captain and
manager of the varsity ball team,
George •A. Stewart was re-elected
treasurer of the Athletic Association, and Seymour S. Merrick was
elected recording secretary to the
Athletic Board.
The Athletic Board for the ensuing year is:
President-John M. Holmes.
Vice-President-Alan M. Chesney.
Treasurer-George A, Stewart.
Corresponding Secretary-Harry
C. Burgan.
Recording Secretary-S. S. Merrick.
Faculty Delegates-Drs. R. T.
Abercrombie and Edward Renouf.
Alumni Delegates-Horace Burroughs, Benjamin H. Griswold, Jr.,
and William C. Schmeisser.
Senior Delegates-E. Brodie
Clary and J. Rainey Wolfe.
Junior Delegate-John S. Fulton, Jr.
Sophomore Delegate-Ernest J.
Pieper.

THE NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 5,

ARBITRATION SOCIETY
New Organization Proposed to Forward
the Cause of International Peace.
Bobbitt the Leader.

Among the features of the coming session, one that promises to
be of more than ordinary importance is a proposed Arbitration Society to be organized shortly by
members of the University who are
interested in promoting the movement for international peace. Mr.
L. B. Bobbitt, of the senior class,
is working actively, to secure the
formation of such an organization
and he believes that sufficient interest in the cause can be aroused to
insure some enthusiastic work
among the students.
The purpose of the new society
will be chiefly educational. A
knowledge of what is being done
by the leading thinkers of all nations to abolish war should be a
part of every educated man's equipment; and it is the hope of the organizers of the new society to make
Hopkins a center of information
and progress in this line.
A group of such organizations
as is planned is doing effective
work among the colleges of the
Middle West under the guidance
and control of the Intercollegiate
Peace Association. College societies of this kind are becoming recognized as one of the most effective
methods of advancing the cause of
peace among the coming men of
the nation.
A meeting of all interested in
the formation of such an organization will be held in Levering Hall,
on next Monday, at i o'clock.
• Mr. Bobbitt will at that time outline the plans for the work and
arrange for the launching of the
movement. As is well known in
Baltimore, he has already distinguished himself by winning the
prize for the best essay by an
American college student on the
subject of International Arbitration, and has attended several of
the conferences at Lake Mohonk,
New York, where he has come into
contact with the great leaders of
the peace movement.

Y. M. C. A. ACTIVITIES
An effort is being made by the
University Y. M. C. A. to organize
for the present session the largest
and most earnest Bible classes that
have ever been held. To accomplish this end some of the strongest
and most interesting leaders to be
found anywhere have been put in
charge of the classes, and through
their efforts the students will be
assured interesting and profitable
courses. It is especially urged that
the freshmen enroll themselves in
the class in the "Life of Christ," to
be conducted especially for them.
The courses offered will be as
follows:
The Life of Christ, Studies in
the- Acts, The Earlier Prophets,
The Social Teachings of Jesus, Old
Testament Studies.
The leaders will be:
F. A. Magruder, J. I. Tracey,
J. F. Hunter, A. B. Morton, H. B.
Hering, J. M. Holmes and R. V. D.
Magoffin.
The opening reception of the
Medical School branch of the Y. M.
C. A. will be held on Thursday
evening of this week in the Association rooms at the hospital. A
general invitation to the students
and their friends is extended.
Under the direction of the General
Secretary, Dr. T. D. Sloan, an interesting program has been prepared which promises an agreeable
evening to all who attend.
The usual reception for the new
students—and old ones, too—is to
be held in Levering Hall, on Friday evening, at 8 o'clock. A general social good time will be the
feature of the occasion, and those
who have attended similar functions know that good fellowship
and sociability will be much in evidence. The following talks, which
are styled "Official Forecasts," will
be given:
"Johns Hopkins University," President Remsen ; "Athletics," A. M.
Chesney; "Publications," T. B.
Price; "Haresfoot Club," N. W.
Haynes;"Y. M. C. A.," H. B. Herring; "Football," Coach Thomas
Lynn.
After the speaking, which will
be short and to the point, it is announced that vacancies in the De-

HE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 1.
MEDICAL SCHOOL
Reopens Session for the Year With a
Large Entering Class.

The Medical Department of the
University opened its session on
Tuesday, October 4. According to
expectation, the entering class is a
large one, about 115 being enrolled
so far. There are also about 25
entering with advanced standing,
an unusually large number.
Among the new students known
in Baltimore are the following:
John T. King, Jr. (Princeton,
'ro); Miss Mabel Belt (Goucher,
'To); Miss Alma Rothholz (Smith,
'Jo); Alan C. Woods(Johns Hopkins, ro); Miss M. L. Frazee (Goucher, 'o8) • Walter C. Haupt (Ph.
D. Johns Hopkins, 'o8).
Among the former students returning, none received a heartier
welcome than Hampden, of the second year, who was forced to leave
his classes by illness during the
past winter.
Several minor improvements to
the grounds have been made during
the summer. The handsome new
concrete wall around the north side
of the lot, which was wrecked just
as it was completed by the severe
storm of September i has now
been entirely repaired and will soon
be turned over by the contractors.
A similar wall now replaces the former unsightly wall of the Hunterian Laboratory. Returning students were also interested in the
progress of the new buildings in
the Hospital grounds. The Harriet
Lane Home and the addition to the
Pathological Building have nearly
reached completion, and the longdelayed Phipps Clinic is fairly under way.
The expected radical change in
the schedules has not entirely materialized, but a step has been taken
by devoting the whole of one day
to the physiological laboratory work
of the second year. The new entering class will take this work in
their first year, in the Spring Trimester.
Mr. Allen of the second class,
is the new member of the Students'
Book Store.
The lectures on the Herter Foundation will be given on October 5,/'
6 and 7 in the Physiological Building by Dr. Hans Chiari, Professor
of Pathological Anatomy at Strassburg, Germany. His subjects are
as follows:
October 5-Die Bedeutung des
Amnoin far die Entstehung von
Missbildungen des Menschen.
• October 6-Pankreasnecrose.
October 7-Spondylolisthesis.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 5, 1910.
Physicians and medical students
are invited to attend. The lectures
will be delivered in German-the
G. \V. C.
hour is 4 P. M.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
ATHLETIC BOARD MEETS
Football Managers Selected-Fulton and
Pieper Elected Temporary Captains-Board for This Year.

At the first meeting of the Athletic Board last Thursday afternoon,
Billie Haynes was elected manager
of the football team to succeed
Freddie Lee, who resigned. J. E. L.
Holmes was elected assistant manager. Jack Fulton was chosen as
temporary captain of the track team
until the members of the team can
get together and select their leader.
Fulton would make a good captain,
and his election will probably be
confirmed by the team. Harry
Burgan, who managed the track
team so efficiently last season, refused to accept the position again
and Harold B. Hering was chosen
to succeed him.
Pieper, one of the leading spirits
of last year's Independent Nine,
was elected temporary captain and
manager of the varsity ball team,
George •A. Stewart was re-elected
treasurer of the Athletic Association, and Seymour S. Merrick was
elected recording secretary to the
Athletic Board.
The Athletic Board for the ensuing year is:
President-John M. Holmes.
Vice-President-Alan M. Chesney.
Treasurer-George A, Stewart.
Corresponding Secretary-Harry
C. Burgan.
Recording Secretary-S. S. Merrick.
Faculty Delegates-Drs. R. T.
Abercrombie and Edward Renouf.
Alumni Delegates-Horace Burroughs, Benjamin H. Griswold, Jr.,
and William C. Schmeisser.
Senior Delegates-E. Brodie
Clary and J. Rainey Wolfe.
Junior Delegate-John S. Fulton, Jr.
Sophomore Delegate-Ernest J.
Pieper.
What '10 la Doing.

Drew Theological Seminary, Madison, N. J.
John M. Holmes is secretary of
the Hopkins branch of the Young
Men's Christian Association.

Woods and Aaron Robinson are
students at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School.

Francis K. Murray is studying
law at the University of Maryland.
Gilbert W. Rosenthal .is taking a
special course in science, preparatory to entering the Medical School.
Benjamin F. Wallis is a graduate student in geology. e•

THE NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 5,

ARBITRATION SOCIETY
New Organization Proposed to Forward
the Cause of International Peace.
Bobbitt the Leader.

Among the features of the coming session, one that promises to
be of more than ordinary importance is a proposed Arbitration Society to be organized shortly by
members of the University who are
interested in promoting the movement for international peace. Mr.
L. B. Bobbitt, of the senior class,
is working actively, to secure the
formation of such an organization
and he believes that sufficient interest in the cause can be aroused to
insure some enthusiastic work
among the students.
The purpose of the new society
will be chiefly educational. A
knowledge of what is being done
by the leading thinkers of all nations to abolish war should be a
part of every educated man's equipment; and it is the hope of the organizers of the new society to make
Hopkins a center of information
and progress in this line.
A group of such organizations
as is planned is doing effective
work among the colleges of the
Middle West under the guidance
and control of the Intercollegiate
Peace Association. College societies of this kind are becoming recognized as one of the most effective
methods of advancing the cause of
peace among the coming men of
the nation.
A meeting of all interested in
the formation of such an organization will be held in Levering Hall,
on next Monday, at i o'clock.
• Mr. Bobbitt will at that time outline the plans for the work and
arrange for the launching of the
movement. As is well known in
Baltimore, he has already distinguished himself by winning the
prize for the best essay by an
American college student on the
subject of International Arbitration, and has attended several of
the conferences at Lake Mohonk,
New York, where he has come into
contact with the great leaders of
the peace movement.

Y. M. C. A. ACTIVITIES
An effort is being made by the
University Y. M. C. A. to organize
for the present session the largest
and most earnest Bible classes that
have ever been held. To accomplish this end some of the strongest
and most interesting leaders to be
found anywhere have been put in
charge of the classes, and through
their efforts the students will be
assured interesting and profitable
courses. It is especially urged that
the freshmen enroll themselves in
the class in the "Life of Christ," to
be conducted especially for them.
The courses offered will be as
follows:
The Life of Christ, Studies in
the- Acts, The Earlier Prophets,
The Social Teachings of Jesus, Old
Testament Studies.
The leaders will be:
F. A. Magruder, J. I. Tracey,
J. F. Hunter, A. B. Morton, H. B.
Hering, J. M. Holmes and R. V. D.
Magoffin.
The opening reception of the
Medical School branch of the Y. M.
C. A. will be held on Thursday
evening of this week in the Association rooms at the hospital. A
general invitation to the students
and their friends is extended.
Under the direction of the General
Secretary, Dr. T. D. Sloan, an interesting program has been prepared which promises an agreeable
evening to all who attend.
The usual reception for the new
students—and old ones, too—is to
be held in Levering Hall, on Friday evening, at 8 o'clock. A general social good time will be the
feature of the occasion, and those
who have attended similar functions know that good fellowship
and sociability will be much in evidence. The following talks, which
are styled "Official Forecasts," will
be given:
"Johns Hopkins University," President Remsen ; "Athletics," A. M.
Chesney; "Publications," T. B.
Price; "Haresfoot Club," N. W.
Haynes;"Y. M. C. A.," H. B. Herring; "Football," Coach Thomas
Lynn.
After the speaking, which will
be short and to the point, it is announced that vacancies in the De-
